#Text=Hans Witdoeck
#Text=Abraham and Melchizedech
#Text=Hans Witdoeck
#Text=or Jan Witdoeck [ 1 ] ( Antwerp , baptized 8 December 1615 - probably Antwerp , after 1642 ) was a Flemish engraver , draughtsman and art dealer . [ 2 ]
#Text=He belonged to the last generation of reproductive engravers who worked for Rubens ' workshop from the mid 1630s . [ 3 ]
#Text=Life
#Text=Hans Witdoeck was a pupil of the engraver Lucas Vorsterman in the years 1630-1631 .
#Text=Vorsterman had joined Rubens ' workshop around 1617 or 1618 and had established himself as Rubens ' primary engraver since . [ 4 ]
#Text=Hans Witdoeck broke the three-year training contract with Vorsterman after only two years at the instigation of his father .
#Text=He then trained for two years with the painter Cornelis Schut who introduced him to painting .
#Text=He subsequently trained with Rubens where he learned the engraving of large plates .
#Text=After the death of Rubens in 1640 , Witdoeck worked mainly as an art dealer .
#Text=He married Catherina Gommaerts on 24 June 1642 .
#Text=Since there are no further records on Withdoeck following his marriage , it is presumed that he died shortly afterwards . [ 5 ]
#Text=Supper at Emmaus
#Text=Work
#Text=In his early engravings he made for Cornelis Schut , Witdoeck followed a traditional style similar to that of Cornelis Galle and his workshop . [ 3 ]
#Text=This early style was characterized by dry lines using many curves and an emphasis on plasticity .
#Text=Witdoeck made two engravings after paintings of Cornelis Schut and nine Madonna images , usually of a small size . [ 5 ]
#Text=His style became more fluid while he worked at Rubens ' workshop where he produced his best work . [ 3 ]
#Text=At Rubens ' workshop Witdoeck learned to engrave large plates .

#Text=Witdoeck worked between 1634 and 1638 under the close supervision of Rubens on many engravings , including Abraham and Melchizedek , the Adoration of the Magi , the three-part Raising of the Cross , the Supper at Emmaus , Saint Ildefonso receiving the chasuble , Cicero and Demosthenes .
#Text=Rubens specified the year 1638 for all these prints likely so that he only needed to apply for one printing privilege for the lot .
#Text=The following year an Assumption of Mary and the Miracle of St. Just by Witdoeck were published .
#Text=Witdoeck also produced a few undated prints while at Rubens ' workshop .
#Text=M. Tullius
#Text=Cicero
#Text=It is clear from the revision and production process of these prints that Rubens was closely involved in their design and execution . [ 5 ]

#Text=This is documented by the process of the creation of a series of twelve plates after antique marble portrait sculptures ( heads , busts , herms ) by the four printmakers Hans Witdoeck , Paulus Pontius , Lucas Vorsterman , and Boetius à Bolswert working for Rubens .
#Text=The production of the prints was closely supervised by Rubens as is demonstrated by five retouched proof impressions .
#Text=Only six of Rubens ' preparatory drawings for the series have survived . [ 6 ]
#Text=Witdoeck showed in his prints after Rubens a great skill in capturing the movement and variety of colour in the original works through his clever use of black , grey and white tones .
#Text=A typical example is Abraham and Melchizedek . [ 3 ]
